item.title: By: Drachefly
item.dc:creator: Drachefly
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/polarized/#comment-140908">Gerald Lester</a>.
Don't forget that the years are not directly comparable in many ways - the bills offered for vote are not the same from year to year. Some conservative and liberal bills of today would fail terribly in a bipartisan way 20 or 30 years ago.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Gerald Lester.

Don’t forget that the years are not directly comparable in many ways – the bills offered for vote are not the same from year to year. Some conservative and liberal bills of today would fail terribly in a bipartisan way 20 or 30 years ago.

item.title: By: isinger
item.dc:creator: isinger
item.description:
Sam Brownback (your illustration for 0 out of 5) is from Kansas, not from Nebraska.
I'm at 4 out of 5 myself.
Finding hope in empirical evidence that things are indeed much worse than they used to be--well, that's a neat trick!
item.content:encoded:
Sam Brownback (your illustration for 0 out of 5) is from Kansas, not from Nebraska.

I’m at 4 out of 5 myself.

Finding hope in empirical evidence that things are indeed much worse than they used to be–well, that’s a neat trick!

item.title: By: CDeFnorthernVermont
item.dc:creator: CDeFnorthernVermont
item.description: 5 out of five, and yes I do live in Vermont.
item.content:encoded: 5 out of five, and yes I do live in Vermont.

item.title: By: Sharad Goel
item.dc:creator: Sharad Goel
item.description: The ADA data are available from <a href="http://www.sscnet.ucla.edu/polisci/faculty/groseclose/Adj.Int.Group.Scores/" rel="nofollow">Timothy Groseclose</a>, and Groseclose, Levitt, and Snyder report some interesting results about the shifts in their article, "<a href="http://www.jstor.org/pss/2585759" rel="nofollow">Comparing Interest Group Scores Across Time and Chambers: Adjusted ADA Scores for the U.S. Congress</a>." (See the newly added note at the end of the post.)
item.content:encoded: The ADA data are available from Timothy Groseclose, and Groseclose, Levitt, and Snyder report some interesting results about the shifts in their article, “Comparing Interest Group Scores Across Time and Chambers: Adjusted ADA Scores for the U.S. Congress.” (See the newly added note at the end of the post.)

item.title: By: Gerald Lester
item.dc:creator: Gerald Lester
item.description: Is the data used in the chart available?? Have you used it to look at trends? For instance, it looks to me like the Democrats moved left starting about 1970-1980 whereas the Republicans moved right some in the House, more so in the Senate. The Republican lower range seems consistent but the Democrat upper range is more pronounced. It would be interesting to run some mathematical trends to catch the timing of the movement.
item.content:encoded: Is the data used in the chart available?? Have you used it to look at trends? For instance, it looks to me like the Democrats moved left starting about 1970-1980 whereas the Republicans moved right some in the House, more so in the Senate. The Republican lower range seems consistent but the Democrat upper range is more pronounced. It would be interesting to run some mathematical trends to catch the timing of the movement.
